byline.contributor: Alisa Sopova reported from Chongar, and Neil MacFarquhar from Moscow. Ivan Nechepurenko contributed reporting from Moscow.
byline.original: By ALISA SOPOVA and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

abstract: More than 1.2 people in Crimea remain without electrical power after Ukrainian nationalists attacked crews attempting to repair electricity pylons destroyed by vandals presumed to be separatists; power cutoff has prompted new level of standoff between Moscow and Kiev, and political tensions continue to rise, evidenced by announcement from Russian gas company Gazprom that it will cut off all gas supplies to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As Crimean Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists prevented repair crews from getting to downed electricity pylons, Kiev closed its airspace to Russian planes and Moscow cut off gas supplies to Ukraine.

headline.main: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimea Power Outage
headline.print_headline: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimean Power Cutoff

snippet: As Crimean Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists prevented repair crews from getting to downed electricity pylons, Kiev closed its airspace to Russian planes and Moscow cut off gas supplies to Ukraine.
